content: As i am a beginner in learning guitar, can you show me all the major chords I need to know

Absolutely! Here are some of the most common major open chord shapes that every beginner guitarist should learn:

1. E Major (E shape): Place your first finger on the second fret of the B string (2nd string), and your second finger on the fourth fret of the G string (3rd string). Strum all six strings.

![E Major Chord](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20width='64'%20height='59'%3E%3Crect%20x='0'%20y='0'%20rx='3'%20ry='3'%20width='58'%20height='58'%20style='fill:#ccc;stroke:#333;stroke-width:1;'/%3E%3Ctext%20x='16'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3EF%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='28'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ex%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='39'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ev%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='6'%20y='17'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='10'%3ESlide%201:%20E%20Major%3C/text%3E%3C/svg%3E)

2. A Major (A shape): Place your second finger on the second fret of the D string (4th string), and your third finger on the second fret of the G string (3rd string). Strum all six strings, but exclude the low E string (6th string).

![A Major Chord](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20width='64'%20height='59'%3E%3Crect%20x='0'%20y='0'%20rx='3'%20ry='3'%20width='58'%20height='58'%20style='fill:#ccc;stroke:#333;stroke-width:1;'/%3E%3Ctext%20x='16'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3EA%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='28'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ex%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='39'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ev%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='6'%20y='17'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='10'%3ESlide%202:%20A%20Major%3C/text%3E%3C/svg%3E)

3. D Major (D shape): Place your third finger on the second fret of the G string (3rd string), and your first finger on the second fret of the B string (2nd string). Strum all six strings.

![D Major Chord](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20width='64'%20height='59'%3E%3Crect%20x='0'%20y='0'%20rx='3'%20ry='3'%20width='58'%20height='58'%20style='fill:#ccc;stroke:#333;stroke-width:1;'/%3E%3Ctext%20x='16'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3ED%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='28'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ex%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='39'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ev%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='6'%20y='17'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='10'%3ESlide%203:%20D%20Major%3C/text%3E%3C/svg%3E)

4. G Major (G shape): Place your first finger on the third fret of the D string (4th string), and your third finger on the fourth fret of the B string (2nd string). Strum all six strings, but exclude the high E string (1st string).

![G Major Chord](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20width='64'%20height='59'%3E%3Crect%20x='0'%20y='0'%20rx='3'%20ry='3'%20width='58'%20height='58'%20style='fill:#ccc;stroke:#333;stroke-width:1;'/%3E%3Ctext%20x='16'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3EG%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='28'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ex%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='39'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ev%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='6'%20y='17'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='10'%3ESlide%204:%20G%20Major%3C/text%3E%3C/svg%3E)

5. C Major (C shape): Place your second finger on the third fret of the G string (3rd string), and your first finger on the first fret of the B string (2nd string). Strum all six strings.

![C Major Chord](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20width='64'%20height='59'%3E%3Crect%20x='0'%20y='0'%20rx='3'%20ry='3'%20width='58'%20height='58'%20style='fill:#ccc;stroke:#333;stroke-width:1;'/%3E%3Ctext%20x='16'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3EC%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='28'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ex%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='39'%20y='44'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='15'%3Ev%3C/text%3E%3Ctext%20x='6'%20y='17'%20font-family='Arial'%20font-size='10'%3ESlide%205:%20C%20Major%3C/text%3E%3C/svg%3E)

These are the five most common open major chords that every beginner should start with. Practice these shapes and their fingerings daily, and you'll be playing simple songs in no time!
